Nah, that's not true.
That might very well be the actual weight of the electrons that make up the data, BUT it is literally a single string of "1's and 0's". There is NO (usable) INFORMATION contained in there on its' own. Are these 3 bytes an integer or 3 characters? And if it is the latter, are these 3 separate characters or is it a string of characters? Is this 20 byte block a ZIP file? If so, how much does the CODE weigh, that decompresses it? MEANING: Without the code that interprets the bits in regards to their actual data type, it is useless.
On the other hand, a lot of those bits are wasted. For instance: A SINGLE 'true' or 'false' value isn't actually stored in a single bit; They are stored in a byte. CPUs cannot address a single bit (that is why we have 'bytes' in the first place. Early computers [and actually 16 bit computers, even] literally couldn't count as high as the amount of bits they had as memory, often not even as high as the amount of BYTES they had as memory). Similarly, most actual numbers waste on average half of their bits.

The answer to this question is WAAAAYYYY more complicated.

5.669904625e-5 grams is the weight of the entire internet according to this video. Let us assume that humanity manages to create a chip that can store all this data
and let's say the dimensions of this super chip are 20 nm x 10 nm x 2nm.
Therefore the volume of this chip is 400nm^3
the density of this chip is 5.669904625*10^-5g/4*10^-9cm^3 (1.41747615625*10^4g/cm^3)
The density of a black hole is 4 × 10^14 g/cm^3.
If we divide the density of a black hole by the density of a "super chip"
we will get the answer as 2.8219169559664330332540646572163*10^10
That is 28219169559.664330332540646572163
The point of all this is if we accelerate the production of the amount of data on the internet and produce 28219169559.6 times the amount of information present on the internet and store within one chip, we can create a black hole just based on that data!

the thing is that while yes, information is stored via electrons, it's not the addition or removal of them. But rather it is a change of state (position) of electrons that are already there. for example, transmitting data over a wireless connection is not actually transporting electrons from one place to another. it is literally high frequency vibrations (sound). sound the data is being moved across or through the medium but isn't carrying any of the medium with it. so, in fact, software has no mass. the same basic principles hold true for electricity also. So even on the ultra microscopic scale a charged batters mass is identical to its unchanged mass. it may very by a few electrons, but even that will naturally balance itself (see static electricity) in a very short time.

Since the Internet is a network, it might be more specifically accurate to talk about the weight of the average data transmission load. So, how much electricity and photons are being used per second (in an average second) to transfer data from here to there rather than what is being stored? Then you could say that the Internet weighs x grams per second.

At the dinner table, I've sometimes tried to explain to my parents and oldest brother that everything is physical. Nothing is actually digital or virtual. At the root of it, it's just electrons and whatnot moving through bits of a computer. My dad understood. My mom began to go on a tangent about the human "soul", and my oldest brother said that I was just trying to boost my ego by showing off how smart I was.

@ 3:31 it is claimed that all the INFORMATION on the internet can be held within the smalles possible grain of sand.
While I understand what you are trying to say, the truth is that just because the total mass of as many electrons as needed to electronically represent all that information is the same as a microsopic grain of sand, saying that the information is HELD in this "lump" of electrons is like saying that a bottle of ink holds all the writings someone may eventually write with it by laying it on a piece of paper with the help of a pen. That's simply not true.
Ink doesn't hold nor contain information, it's just a medium that can eventually be used to represent it, and it can't even do it on it's own. Just as you need a paper and space between the traces so that letters can be written on it, on a computer memory or cable, you need lots of other mechanisms to space and organize these electrons into information that can be later retrieved. Information is not a property of matter. Information is intelligent organization.

So, yes, a microscopic "bottle of electrons" doesn't equal to information.

This video is questionable in more respects. First: A file or a pendrive contains the most information when it has random data (i.e. about 50% zeros and 50% ones). So if a file or a pendrive or a hdd is full of 1-s or 0-s, then it contains the less possible information. Second: The mapping of information to electrons is very doubtful again. The video suggests that information is stored in electrons, i.e. in electric charge. This would mean that a pendrive full of 1-s should have a net negative charge. But do pendrives really behave like charged bodies? Do they attract other charged (or non charged) bodies, like a charged plastic rod does? Do they produce sparks near grounded conductors? According to this theory, they should.

Because 1's have mass, and 0s have none.
So if there are more 0s than 1s in a file, the file will be lighter in weight, as opposed to... eg: A file that's composed of 1s.
Now, since most files can be compressed, and a good compression algorithm aims for an equal amount of 0s and 1s (because it'll try to compress multiple 1s or 0s if it finds them), you can say that a compressed file exists out of 50% the mass calculated, and an uncompressed file can weigh anywhere from 10% to 1000% the weight of a compressed file, depending on if it has more 1s or 0s, and how much the file is compressed.

the weight of the kindle, or any computer also depends on how you are storing the information. If you are using a HDD, or Hard Drive Disk, then the weight would stay completely the same. Because an HDD does not store electrons. It stores information much like a DVD. Inside of the HDD is a metal platter. And to store information, it uses a magnet to put bumps into the metal platter. I think a concave bump is 1, and a flat area is 0. It might be the other way around. But anyways, if for some weird reason a Kindle stored information on a HDD, like most desktops and laptops, then no, the mass would stay the same. because nothing is taken away or added.
Nowadays, it's ~400 grams.

Well, your kindle didn't get heavier, because the electrons used for storage were already in the kindle. If you imagine your kindle as an electronic part, a resistor for example, that is connected to the battery, the electrons just float from the battery's negatively charged part to the positively charged part until both parts are in balance. When you then recharge it, the power'S source is like another big battery, that attracts the electrons in the previously positively charged part and empties it, while the previously negatively charged part is filled up again. So even recharging it doesn't make it heavier... In theory. By using your kindle, some parts emit light or heat up or are loosing electrons for something different, so it actually becomes lighter by using it and becomes heavier recharging it. But not by downloading stuff. Interesting video :)

Of course this assumes that the data is stored on flash when in reality, it's mostly stored on magnetic media. Since in magnetic media it's the arrangement of the mass rather than the addition or subtraction of mass you could argue it weighs nothing, or weighs the weight of the magnetic platter.

Then again, it also presumes that "The Internet" is information, when of course it's arguably not. The Internet is the network that connects the devices together and while information is accessible via the Internet, it's questionable if that information is "The Internet". In the same way if somebody said "How much does the road system weigh" and you start adding up the mass of people transported by that road system.

Guessing that they have to move tens to hundereds of meters through the computer, it will take them hundereds of nanoseconds (or somewhere between 1 and 10 MHz in the original equation). The calculated weight is therefore about two to three orders of magnitude too small, and would be valid if electrons will travel about 10 cm through a computer. Which is less than the length of a typical ATX cable.

It's rather obvious that digitally stored information is extremely light per se.
What's interesting, if you calculate it, the Internet stored as a binary number (bit off = 0 bit on = 1) would have almost 10^20 binary digits (based on the estimate you quoted after Eric Schmidt).
How much is that exactly? Well, assume a single digit is a millimeter wide, millimeter tall, and you have a tape with the "Number of the Internet". Then you could stretch the tape from the Earth to the Moon 100 000 000 000 times, so if you wrap it side-by-side, we'd have a 100 000 kilometers wide tape connecting the Earth to the Moon. 100 000 kilometers around 8 times more than the Earth is wide (diameter). Not bad, considering the digits are so small.

You could do a video estimating the maximum amount of information the universe could store. You could estimate the degrees of freedom for a single particle in your "universe computer" and log2(degrees_of_freedom) is how many bits 1 particle can store. That'd be an interesting estimate! And I'm not even touching storing information as waves, energy, or fields...

Infinity is in a class of numbers known as "hyper-real" numbers. Information takes a long time to load because it has to be processed and saved.  All these actions happen at specific time intervals defined by a clock. The clock-rate is typically not that high to make sure the information doesn't get all mixed up. Also, the data has to be transferred one at a time in little packets and not just all at once. Depending on the download protocol, there is a constant feedback system in place to make sure you got the right information, and that takes time as well.

You redistribute charges when you recharge a battery. The amount of charge (aka electrons) in the battery is the same, it's just no longer evenly distributed (like it is in a dead battery).

Potential energy is an imbalance. You're not raising the level of electrons in a battery, you're moving them around. Raising one side of a see-saw doesn't make it weigh more, even if you raise the heavier side. The weight of the system remains constant, despite the potential energy in the system increasing. Energy/matter equivalence doesn't come into it, you've still got the same matter,

As far as I know, electrons go wherever there are fewer electrons, hence why the current flows(which is why you need an electrolyte between the anode and the cathode), but in the process, you don't lose electrons. You recharge the battery by rearranging them back into their order. Not sure how the story goes about transferring data though.

I might be wrong, but it's as much as I can remember off the top of my head.

Vsauce does not target the issue. Sure... electrons are used to send information between all devices but when it comes to storing "the internet" it is a whole different thing.

Solid State Drives are the exception cases. The data on an SSD is actually stored with electrons. The weight of "The Internet" is therefore equal only to the amount of electrons used in ALL SSD's connected to the Internet.
The Weight of the Internet, © Zinke

The majority of storage today is mechanical. Mechanical means that the data is stored on magnetic disks. The data is binary (1 and 0) and the direction of the magnetic field at a certain point determines whether the field is interpreted as a "1" or "0". The majority of the Internet is therefore stored in magnetic fields and as far as scientists know today, magnetic fields do not have any weight.

"The Internet" consists of basically all content on any computer that is connected to it. Whether other people can access it or not is a different question, so basically everything is part of the internet. The actual electrons carry information back and forth everywhere but that doesnt mean that [the amount of electrons = the internet]. We need to look at where the Internet is being stored before we can even think about measuring its weight.

Basic electrical engineering, really. Batteries don't use up electrons and require new electrons to be charged, the electrons move from the negative pole of the battery to the positive pole when "used", and move back when you recharge the battery. No mass is gained in the charging process (or lost in the discharging process), so the mass is the same. The same idea applies to the operation of memory, be it RAM or solid-state non-volatile memory. Electrons are moved, not added or removed.

The problem with this idea is that the premise is kind of flawed. A computer storage device has empty space on it most of the time, but this 'empty' space usually has random data on it. So it would have a weight indistinguishable from that of the actual data itself, regardless of the precise details of what determines the weight of data. (aside from which; does a binary 0 weigh a different amount to a binary 1?). Therefore, it's unlikely the weight of a device would change.

Not even close!  Information does NOT weigh anything.  The medium it is expressed in has weight, but the actual information contained is not a matter of mass.  Here is an example:
You have a pile of sticks.  Together they weigh a total of 20 pounds.  If you arrange them so that they appear in the form of letters that spell out: I Love You.  They now contain information, however, their combined weight has not changed.  Period.

Well assuming that the average blue whale weighs around 177 metric tons (which is the weight of the largest blue whale ever weighed and assuming that the internet weighs 56.70 micrograms (0.000002 ounces) it's easy enough to work out.

A blue whale weighs 177,000,000,000,000 micrograms.

56.70/177,000,000,000,000
=3.2033898e-13 OR 0.000000000000320338983050

Which means that the internet weighs around 0.32 trillionths of a blue whale.

Actually this video is false as data is stored on hard drives. Hard drives do not gain mass from information being stored on them. They use magnetism to store data and not electrons. Only if the data were being stored on flash drives (USB keys) Or SSDs (Which are not in common use yet) Would it have mass.

NO. A. This video is false as hard drives (Which are the main thing computers and internet servers use for data storage) don't gain weight from having information stored on them. B. If the data is stored on a flash drive (USB key) Or an SSD (Not commonly used yet) Then it gains mass from electrons, AKA electricity.

Why isn't anyone pointing out how this video is false as data isn't usually stored on memory? Currently data is stored on hard drives, which don't gain weight from having more information on them as they use magnetism. If it is stored on RAM, Flash drives, or SSDs then yes it gains weight. Thing is internet servers don't use SSDs for the ungodly price they would cost.
@TheMojNetwork Seriously that's a great question

Basically information stored on memory (RAM, and Flash drives, and SSDs) has weight. As the difference between a 1 and a 0 is an electron, and electrons have mass. However this video is false as Hard drives do not gain mass when information is stored on them, as they use magnetism to indicated a 1 and a 0.

I don't know when Eric Schmidt made that estimation of 5 million terabytes, but it is a ridiculously small number. Current consumption rate of harddrives is about 200 million drives per quarter (800 million per year). And the drive capacity average is pretty close to 1 terabyte.  5 million terabytes is nothing for the internet nowadays

You assume that internet is stored on flash memories, which is absolutely wrong. Almost all servers use mechanical hard drives to store data. They use limited amount of flash storage at the front end of the server for fast response. Mechanical hard drives don't use electrons in the way flash does. They use magnetic clusters. And you calculation is not relevant to hard drives, which make more than 99% of the internet. Sorry for ruining your video...

A more accurate question would be "How much does the data travelling through the internet weigh?"  Because right now he makes it sound like the entire internet.  Well the entire Internet is made up of a ton of hardware that weighs A LOT.  That data needs to have a server hosting it somewhere, a means to travel through the internet, cables, fibre, etc. .A way to switch from network to network... routers and switches.. all of these physical devices have mass.

@izaq4444 
About the proton: It was there to begin with. So the device is no heavier or lighter than before. We just moved a number of electrons from one electrode to the other. ;)

@reach4blackops 
If you take a flash device and write a logic 1 or 0 you do that by sending a current (of electrons) through the device. In a current an equal amount of electrons enter and leave the device. So the description of "placing an electron" is only valid for the one electrode. Another electron leaves the device. Hence the devices weighs the same.

The internet weighs nothing! 

The explanation in the video is bogus. If you put an electron in a flash cell the electrical field would cause the same the same positive charge to be stored on the opposing side of the capacitor. The positive charge is the lack of an electron. 

Hence, putting an electron in a flash device makes an electron leave the device. (Or else there would be no current running through the device either).

Fourth: When charging a bettery you ARE NOT delivering electrons.  Power companies do not sell electrons, they sell energy.  You are supplying electrons that are already there with energy to possibly move when allowed to (current).  Manipulating these voltages( energy per charge) and currents (flowing electrons) gives us the 1s and 0s, bits that make up information.  You cannot weigh the internet.  The whole premise is flawed.

This whole video is incredibly misleading.  First: A gram is not a measure of weight, it is a measure of mass.  Sceond: One electron does not comprise a bit (1 or 0) by itself.  An entire transistor will represent a 1 or 0, which although quite small and getting smaller, is much larger than one electron.  Third:  That transistor relies on high and low voltages (energy per charge) to determine 1s and 0s, not the presence of an electron

This doesn't make any sense.  Electrons don't appear out of nowhere.  They already existed, in the metal of the traces, in the chips, in the battery, etc.  You're simply changing where the electrons are located in the ebook reader.  And in fact, when you erase flash memory, you're setting every bit to '1'.  So writing a book to an ebook reader is actually decreasing the electrons used in the flash chips.  But either way, they still exist in the unit, they just move elsewhere.

Data size measurements are based on a scale of 1000, not 1 million.

1 Byte is the smallest size of data an average user will deal with.
1000 Bytes = 1 Kilobyte
1000 Kilobytes = 1 Megabyte
1000 Megabytes = 1 Gigabyte
1000 Gigabytes = 1 Terabyte
1000 Terabytes =  1 Petabyte
1000 Petabytes = 1 Exabyte
and so on and so forth.

2:04 There’s a fundamental flaw regarding how much the stored data weighs.  Today, we do store some of our data in flash memory, such as thumb drives and SSD drives.  However, the majority is stored on HDD’s which store the data as magnetic flux.  The data is written using electrons, but once it is written, the data consists of magnetic charges, not electrons.  It would be interesting to know how much magnetic charge the internet has compared to a refrigerator magnet, or something like that.
